huntYears.SEASON_DATE_TEXT: Any open season on any bear unit during the 2022 season.
huntYears.NOTES: The 2022 conservation statewide black bear permit can be obtained through the Mule Deer Foundation The 2022 Statewide bear sportsman's permit can be obtained by Utah residents by applying in the sportsman's draw from Oct 20 through Nov 10, 2021.

huntMaster.PRINT_HUNT_NAME: Black Bear Statewide Permit - Hunt# BR1000
huntMaster.SPECIAL_PROVISIONS: This permit is available as the Statewide Sportsman's Permit by applying for the permit in the late fall or by obtaining the Statewide Conservation Permit available to purchase through the approved conservation organization. See guidebook or contact a regional office for details.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: Required: Any harvested bear must be checked by a DWR employee within 48 hours of the date of kill. The DWR employee will affix a permanent possession tag to the pelt or unskinned carcass. You may not possess an unskinned carcass or green pelt after the 48 hour check-in period. If you need to reach a Division employee after regular business hours, over a weekend, or on a holiday, contact your local police dispatch. In addition, you cannot ship a green pelt out of the state of Utah or present it to a taxidermist if the pelt does not have a permanent possession tag attached.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP:
The majority of land is managed by the BLM. There is a significant amount of SITLA land. There are several DWR Wildlife Management Areas (WMA). These areas are managed for wildlife and you can hunt on all these areas. There is private land and some of it is accessible through the DWR’s Walk-in-Access Program
http://wildlife.utah.gov/walkinaccess/
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Meadow Creek, Two Waters, Bitter Creek, and Willow Creek.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Please direct all questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Vernal BLM Field Office (http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html) BLM: 14 day camping limit and you have to move 30 miles after 14 days. DWR WMA’S: UDWR WMAs are limited to 14 days at one location. On the Willow Creek WMA, camping is not allowed. In the parcels that can be accessed by county roads there is no camping allowed. Camping is only allowed in the parcels where the roads are closed, like Meadow Creek.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The Seep Ridge road is the best way to access where the bison are located.  You can stay on this road until you come to the Book Cliffs Divide.  Once on the Divide road I would travel west to Winter Ridge and Rock Springs Mesa.  You can also access the Divide from I-70 using the Hay Canyon Road.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads.  There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, SITLA, and DWR, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Vernal BLM Field Office and SITLA. The DWR WMA’s are restricted to ATV and vehicle travel on established roads and trails.
This unit includes the Book Cliffs Little Creek WMA (Roadless Area). There is no vehicle access in this area and you are limited to horse or foot travel.

Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads. There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.
The Book Cliffs offers a challenging landscape. There are large ridges with steep canyons dividing them. Most of the canyons and ridges have roads or ATV trails to provide access. There are plenty of areas to hike and get away from the main roads. The hunting pressure will drastically decrease after opening weekend.
There are two roads that allow you to drive across the majority of the Book Cliffs. The Kings Well Road starts at the Seep Ridge Road on the west side, and it can take you all the way to the Dragon Road on the east side. The Indian Ridge Road starts at the Seep Ridge Road and goes through the bottom of Sweetwater, the top of McCook Ridge, Bitter Creek and to Big Park. It is a great road to locate deer during this time of year.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The boundary excludes all of the Tribal Trust Lands. There is a large area of Ute Tribal Trust land to the west of the hunt unit. Road access across the Tribal land is permitted using county roads. All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands; they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal lands.
There are some private ranches that post their property. There are also privately owned lands that allow access through the DWR Walk-in-Access Program.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Grand and Uintah counties--Boundary begins at Exit 164 on I-70 near the town of Green River; east on I-70 to the Utah-Colorado state line; north on this state line to the White River; west along this river to the Green River; south along this river to Swasey's Boat Ramp and the Hastings Road; south on this road to SR-19; south and east on SR-19 to Exit 164 on 1-70 near the town of Green River. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THE BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Huntington, Seep Ridge, Westwater. Boundary questions? Call the Price office, 435-613-3700 or the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by SITLA and DWR. There is a large DWR Wildlife Management Area (WMA) known as the Little Creek WMA. This area is managed for wildlife and the DWR encourages hunting on all WMA’s.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Little Creek.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads. 
DWR WMA’S: UDWR WMAs is limited to 14 days at one location.  
There are no established campgrounds in this unit, it is a first-come first-served basis.  Some hunters prefer to camp at the trailheads.  There are DWR cabins in this unit that are not for public use.  There is no camping allowed within a quarter mile of a DWR cabin.  

The trails are seasonally maintained by the DWR, and sportsmen.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
There are two trailheads for the roadless area, a north and a south.  The north access is called the Ten Mile Knoll trailhead.   If you take Utah State Road 88, it is located between Vernal and Roosevelt.  Follow SR 88 south and it turns into the Seep Ridge Road.  The Seep Ridge Rd splits and becomes the Divide Rd.  If you take the Divide Rd west the trail head is at the start of Steer Ridge.  There is a sign at the parking area.  It is a large parking area but it can fill up in a hurry with trucks and horse trailers.  The Hay Canyon Rd is the main access road on the south side of the Book Cliffs.  You can access it from I-70.  It is a hard packed dirt/gravel road.  The Steer Ridge Rd can be very dangerous if it has been snowing or raining but it can dry out quickly.

The south trail head starts at the top of Sego Canyon.  The road starts at Thompson Springs in Grand County and continues up the Sego Canyon Rd; follow it to the end of the road.  There is a water trough at the trailhead but it is not always full of water.  This trailhead can also fill up with vehicles and trailers.  There are no bathrooms or other facilities at either of these trailheads, so plan accordingly.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads.  There are several county signs, and BLM signs to help direct you.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
This area has strict travel constraints.  It is limited to horse and foot travel.  Sportsmen should take this into account before they put in for this unit.  The Steer Ridge Rd is one road that borders the northeast boundary of the unit.  There are no other roads around this unit.   

The Book Cliffs offers a challenging landscape.  There are large ridges with steep canyons dividing them.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The Ute Tribe as agreed to allow sportsmen to access this area across Ute Tribal trust lands.  Once you leave the Sego Trailhead parking area and start down the Went Ridge trail you are on Tribal land for the first few miles.  There are signs indicating that you have permission from the Tribe to use this route.  We ask that you please keep this area clean and stay on the main trail until you are off of Ute Tribal land.  This is a privilege and abuse of this area could lead to sportsmen losing this access permit.  This hunt excludes all Ute Tribal lands.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Grand County--Boundary begins at the Steer Ridge road at Ten Mile Knoll and the Book Cliffs summit (north-south drainage divide); southwest along the Book Cliffs summit on Diamond Ridge to the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation boundary (Hells Hole/head of Sego Canyon); north on this boundary (west side of West Willow Creek) to the DWR Wildlife Management Area/Ute Tribe Fence at the confluence of East and West Willow Creek; northeast from this confluence; cross-country to the Steer Ridge road (NW 1/4 Sec 7, T17S R21E); south and east on the Steer Ridge road (atop the drainage divide) to Ten Mile Knoll and the Book Cliffs summit. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Westwater. Boundary questions? Call Vernal office, 435-781-9453.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Most of the upper elevation habitat occurs on Forest Service lands managed by the Manti La Sal National Forest.  BLM and State-owned public lands exist in the foothill portions of the unit.  There are large blocks of private land in the area surrounding Scofield Reservoir, along SR-31 in the lower reaches of the Canyon, and in the irrigated valleys at low elevations.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Gordon Creek WMA west of Price, Lower Fish Creek WMA near Scofield Reservoir, Starvation WMA near SR-6, Dairy Fork WMA near SR-6, Lake Fork WMA near SR-6, Birdseye WMA on US-89, and Lasson Draw WMA near US-89
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Campgrounds are available on Forest Service and BLM lands.  Contact the Manti-La Sal National Forest at 435 637-2817 or the Price BLM office at (435) 636-3600 for campground information.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: Primary access points include North Skyline Drive from SR-6, SR-96 accessing the Scofield area, Ford Ridge from SR-6 near the top of Price Canyon, the Consumers Road near the town of Helper, SR-31 connecting Huntington and Fairview, Thistle Creek Road off of US-89, Lake Fork Road off of US-89, Dairy Fork, Mill Fork and Starvation Roads off of SR-6
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 maps include Price, Nephi, Huntington
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: Large blocks of private land prevail in the area surrounding Scofield Reservoir.  Private lands dominate at low elevations near most of the major streams and towns

USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Huntington, Manti, Nephi, Price. Boundary questions? Call the Springville office, 801-491-5678

Many of these campgrounds are popular on weekends throughout the summer.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of the land within this unit is managed by federal and state land management agencies and thus open to hunting with general season permits but not Private Land Only permits. There are several large ranches within the unit, several of which are enrolled in the CWMU program for Big game. Consult accurate land ownership maps before going afield.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: n/a
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: <u>Campground information:</u> There are many improved Camping areas on the Fish Lake unit, both public and private. Good camping exists in Gooseberry area, Elk Horn, multiple areas around Fish Lake and Johnson Reservoir. Primitive camping is allowed on much of the BLM and USFS managed lands. There is one improved campground managed by the Piute tribe near Koosharem reservoir. During early spring some campgrounds are not accessible or open. Contact the managing agency for detailed information.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: There are many ways to access this unit. During the winter and early spring many of these roads (especially the upper elevation sections) may be closed due to snow. The north end can be accessed off of I-70 at the Gooseberry exit and also at the Hwy 72 exit. There are also many smaller unimproved roads that get you into good country from the frontage road along I-70. Access to the eastern side of the unit is via hwy 72. Roads that fork from hwy 72 that get you into good county include the Last Chance road, Road #206 that gets you onto the Thousand Lake Mountain, road #036 that takes you past Mill Meadow Reservoir and to Fish Lake.  There are many ATV trails and smaller unimproved roads that fork off of Hwy 72. The main access on the south end is SR-25 to Fish Lake via SR-24.   The west side is accessed via several dirt roads including the Hancock Flat road off of SR-25,  Road #053 that forks off of SR-24 gets you into the Rex Reservoir, and the Lost Creek country.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100.000 Maps: Loa, Salina. Fish Lake National Forest Travel Map
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: There is an expansive road and trail system on this unit. All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, USFS, Sevier and Wayne counties. Most Travel regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated to the Fish Lake National Forest, Richfield and Loa offices. BLM offices are in Richfield and Loa. The USFS has a travel map that covers most of this area.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There are several large tracts of private property on this unit. Several of these tracts are enrolled in the CWMU program and require special permits to hunt on them. Consult a good map to ensure you know where you are and to avoid any trespass conflicts
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Emery, Piute, Sevier and Wayne counties—Boundary begins at I-70 and SR-24 north of Sigurd; south and east on SR-24 to the Caineville Wash road; north on this road to the Cathedral Valley road; west on this road to Rock Springs Bench and the Last Chance Desert road; north on this road to the Blue Flats road; north and east on this road to the Willow Springs road; north on this road towards Windy Peak and the Windy Peak road; west on this road to SR-72; north on SR-72 to I-70; west on I-70 to SR-24 north of Sigurd. huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by the BLM.  There is a significant amount of SITLA land.  There are several DWR Wildlife Management Areas (WMA).  These areas are managed for wildlife and you can hunt on all these areas.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Meadow Creek, Two Waters, Bitter Creek, Willow Creek, and Nash Wash WMAs.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
Please direct all questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Vernal BLM Field Office (http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html)
BLM:  14 day camping limit and you have to move 30 miles after 14 days. 
DWR WMA’S:  UDWR WMAs is limited to 14 days at one location.  On the Willow Creek WMA, camping is not allowed.  In the parcels that can be accessed by county roads there is no camping allowed.  Camping is only allowed in the parcels where the roads are closed, like Meadow Creek.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: Seep Ridge Road (UT 88) and the Bonanza Highway/Atchee Ridge Road (UT 45) from the North, Hay Canyon from I-70 on the South
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads. There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, SITLA, and DWR, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Vernal BLM Field Office, and SITLA. The DWR WMA’s are restricted to ATV and vehicle travel on established roads and trails.

The Book Cliffs offers a challenging landscape. There are large ridges with steep canyons dividing them. Most of the canyons and ridges have roads or ATV trails to provide access. There are plenty of areas to hike and get away from the main roads. The hunting pressure will drastically decrease after opening weekend.

There are two roads that allow you to drive across the majority of the Book Cliffs. The Kings Well Rd starts at the Seep Ridge Rd on the west side, and it can take you all the way to the Dragon Rd on the east side. The Indian Ridge Road starts at the Seep Ridge Rd and goes through the bottom of Sweet Water, top of McCook Ridge, Bitter Creek, and to Big Park. It is a great road to locate wildlife during this time of year.

Interstate 70 will provide access to most of the drainages on the south side of the Book Cliffs. Wildlife are found often found in these canyons. Major canyons and access points include Thompson/Sego Canyon, Nash Wash, Cottonwood Canyon, Hay/Middle/East Canyons, and Bryson Canyon. There are roads that will take you to the top of the Book Cliffs only in Sego Canyon, Hay Canyon, East Canyon, and Bitter Creek. The remainder of the roads dead end a short way up the canyons.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public lands are all Forest Service lands managed by the Ashley and Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forests.  This unit includes a large portion of the High Uintas Wilderness Area where all motor vehicles are prohibited.  This unit also includes large tracts of Ute tribal lands that are closed to non-tribal members.  The tribal lands are mostly the lower elevation sagebrush zone but in some areas they reach up into the aspen/conifer zone.  There is a large amount of private property on the unit too.  Most of the private property is below the tribal boundary but there are several parcels of private property in the canyon bottoms.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Little Montes Creek WMA north of Ballard and Kevin Conway WMA southeast of Myton.  Elk, bear and cougar are rarely found on these WMAs.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP:
The vast majority of the habitat from Argyle Canyon south is privately owned. Many of these properties are enrolled in the CWMU program where a separate hunting permit is required for big game on their property and they can not allow access. On this part of the unit there are only small isolated parcels of public lands on summer ranges to hunt. Prior permission must be secured before hunting on private lands. There is more public land on the northern third of the unit near Anthro Mountain. There is a mix of USFS and BLM lands in this area although wildlife densities tend to be lower in this area.

Anthro Subunit
Public, Private and Tribal Lands. The public lands are primarily US Forest Service lands managed by the Ashley National Forest and The Bureau of Land Management(BLM) managed out of the Vernal Field Office. This unit also includes large tracks of Ute Tribal lands that are closed to non-tribal members. The Tribal lands are mostly on the North end of the unit in the pinyon/juniper belt, with heavy oil field activity. The private land on the unit is primarily North of the Tribal boundary and in the low elevation desert areas and agricultural lands. There are two CWMU's on the unit (Antelope Creek and Cottonwood Ridge).

Range Creek Subunit
Most of the high elevation summer and early fall habitat is privately owned. Much of this private land occurs on 5 CWMU's (Preston Nutter Ranch, Patmos Ridge, Roan Cliffs, Conover-Jensen, and Minnie Maud CWMU's). Public lands occur at mid elevations and on the winter range. The vast majority of Nine Mile Canyon is privately owned.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT:
The Cold Springs WMA exists on good habitat near the town of Sunnyside

The Cottonwood WMA exists on the Anthro subunit.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
There are no known developed campgrounds on the unit. There are ample opportunities for dispersed camping on BLM and SITLA properties. No camping is allowed on the Cold Springs WMA. Please consult the Price BLM office for any camping restrictions at http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/price.html

Anthro Subunit
There are no official campgrounds on this unit. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the Forest. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites. Ashley National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The Nine Mile Canyon road is accessed from SR6 in Wellington.  It will provide access to Minnie Maud Canyon, lower Argyle Canyon, Harmon Canyon, as well as Cottonwood and Cedar Ridges.  The Bruin Point road is accessed via SR123 in the town of Sunnyside.  This road is impassible during the winter months.

huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO: All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Most major roads are maintained by Carbon, Emery, and Duchesne Counties. The Bruin Point dugway and Cottonwood Canyon dugway are both very steep and should not be attempted if there is a bunch of snow without tire chains. Pulling a camper trailer up the Bruin Point Dugway is possible but difficult. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Price BLM office at http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/price.html

There are several access roads across Tribal Lands in the Anthro Mountain area, for information on which roads are legal access roads contact Duchesne County.  All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands, they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal Lands.

This unit has a high percentage of private property on high elevation summer habitat, much of this property is managed as  CWMU’s. All private land requires written permission before hunting.  On this unit it is absolutely essential to have a map showing land ownership prior to hunting as most public land parcels are small and isolated and often surrounded by posted private property.  A GPS unit is also very handy.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public, Private and Tribal Lands.  Public lands include lands managed by the BLM, USFS (Fish Lake National Forest), and the state of Utah.  Most of the mountainous ground is public land and open to the public. There are both large and small tracts of privately owned property scattered both in the low country and high country. In addition there is a small parcel of tribal land adjacent to Koosharem reservoir
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Elbow Ranch WMA - The Elbow Ranch WMA is a large winter range area. Do not expect high numbers of big game or bears to use this area during most hunting seasons.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: There is only one official campground located on the unit. This campground is owned by the Koosharem Band of Piutes and is located adjacent to Koosharem reservoir. Hotel/camping accommodations exist in cities and towns that surround the unit. There is also a nearby campground at Otter Creek State Park. Camping outside of official campgrounds is permitted on most public ground. Please direct camping questions to the appropriate land management agency. Fishlake National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/fishlake
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: There are several main access roads to the Monroe unit. You can access the north side via road #068 from either the town of Annabella or Glenwood. This is a well maintained gravel road. From the east side you can take road #076 out of Koosharem and #069 out of Greenwich. Road #069 is the best road to take if you are pulling camp a trailer. The south end of the mountain can be accessed with the Pole canyon road (#072) near Angle or the Monroe Mountain road (#068) near Kingston. Both of these are maintained but are rather narrow and not recommended for large trailers. To access the west side of the unit use the Dry Creek road (#071) or the Monroe Canyon road (#078). Both of these roads are not recommended for trailers.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Beaver, Loa, Richfield, Salina.  USFS Travel Management map
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: ATV and Vehicle Access: The Monroe unit has an extensive road and trail system. Many good areas to hunt can be accessed via vehicle. During the early hunting seasons most all roads and trails can be accessed. During later seasons early and heavy snows may make travel difficult. Some trails are restricted to ATVs of a certain size only. Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. Maps can also be purchased online at: http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/fishlake/maps-pubs
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: There are both large and small tracts of privately owned property scattered both in the low elevation and high areas. In addition there is a small parcel of tribal land adjacent to Koosharem reservoir. Please respect all private lands and associated trespass laws.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Piute and Sevier counties—Boundary begins at US-89 and I-70 near Sevier; south on US-89 to SR-62; east and north on SR-62 to SR-24; north on SR-24 to I-70; south on I-70 to US-89 near Sevier. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Beaver, Loa, Richfield, Salina. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Forest Service, BLM, State, Private
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Kingston Canyon WMA is on the north end and has sportsman access, but it is all on foot.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: No campgrounds are located on the unit but dispersed camping is available.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: You can access the south end of the unit from the Tom Best Spring road off of HWY 12. You can access the east side of the unit on several different access point along SR-22 (John's Valley Highway). The north end of the unit is inaccessible except by foot. The west side of the unit can be accessed by several points from Circleville to Panguitch along HWY 89. I would access the top of the mountain using the Jones Corral or Cottonwood loop road.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USFS, and BLM land maps.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: ATV's are a good way to access the units. Several roads are impassible by vehicle so an ATV would be recommended.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Garfield and Piute counties—Boundary begins at US-89 and SR-62; south on US-89 to SR-12; east on SR-12 to the Widtsoe-Antimony Road; north on this road to SR-22; north on SR-22 to SR-62; west on SR-62 to US-89. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Beaver, Escalante, Loa, Panguitch. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public, Private and Parks Service.  The public lands are primarily US Forest Service lands managed by the Manti-La Sal National Forest and The Bureau of Land Management(BLM) managed out of the Moab Field Office.  This unit also includes National Parks Service lands that are closed to hunting.  The private lands are primarily on the Eastern portion of the unit, but there are private lands scattered throughout the unit. There are two CWMU's on the unit (Redd Ranches and JB Ranch).
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All Campgrounds on this subunit are managed by the US Forest Service, Utah State Institutional Trust Lands and the Bureau of Land Management. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the Forest. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service, SITLA or the BLM. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
